articles.headline: E.P.A. Takes Step to Cut Emissions From Planes
articles.snippet: The initiative by the Environmental Protection Agency is part of a broad drive by the Obama administration to combat global warming.
articles.abstract: The initiative by the Environmental Protection Agency is part of a broad drive by the Obama administration to combat global warming.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration said on Wednesday that it would take the first step toward regulating greenhouse gas emissions from airplanes, but it acknowledged it would most likely take years before stringent standards are enacted.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: Michelle Obama Talks About Race and Success, and Makes It Personal
articles.snippet: The first lady has been opening up about her own struggles and the “insults and slights” that even living in the White House has not protected her family from.
articles.abstract: The first lady has been opening up about her own struggles and the “insults and slights” that even living in the White House has not protected her family from.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — She looked around and saw herself three decades ago, young and uncertain, from a part of town where success is a struggle, not a birthright. She knew what they had been through, what it was like to take the long way home to avoid gangs, what it was like when the family strained to make ends meet.

articles.headline: J. Crew Flounders in Fashion’s Shifting Tides
articles.snippet: The retailer’s sales have slumped because of two industrywide trends — “athleisure” wear and fast fashion — but it has also made its share of missteps.
articles.abstract: The retailer’s sales have slumped because of two industrywide trends — “athleisure” wear and fast fashion — but it has also made its share of missteps.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wendy Sherman peered into the J. Crew store at the Mall at Short Hills, and frowned.

articles.headline: Tipping Point in Transit
articles.snippet: The future of driving is in many ways already here, and the changes are coming fast and furious. Many could see lower costs and more convenience, but not everyone may benefit.
articles.abstract: The future of driving is in many ways already here, and the changes are coming fast and furious. Many could see lower costs and more convenience, but not everyone may benefit.
articles.lead_paragraph: One sunny morning a few weeks ago, I slipped into the inviting cockpit of a Mercedes-Benz S550 sedan, a ride equipped with massaging front seats, reclining back seats, a heads-up display worthy of a fighter jet and more speakers than a political convention. At $136,000, this was a car fit for a rap star or a European Union functionary, of which I am neither (yet).

articles.headline: Republicans Tie Their Favorite Causes to the Trade Agreement
articles.snippet: Last-minute additions were appended not to the fast-track bill at the center of the fight, but to a separate bill being considered alongside it.
articles.abstract: Last-minute additions were appended not to the fast-track bill at the center of the fight, but to a separate bill being considered alongside it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a final House showdown coming on Friday on President Obama’s push for accelerated power to pursue a sweeping trade agreement, the vote brokering has begun — and it is all tilting to the right.

articles.headline: Hackers May Have Obtained Names of Chinese With Ties to U.S. Government
articles.snippet: Lost data from the Office of Personnel Management may have included the names of Chinese who could now suffer retaliation.
articles.abstract: Lost data from the Office of Personnel Management may have included the names of Chinese who could now suffer retaliation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Investigators say that the Chinese hackers who attacked the databases of the Office of Personnel Management may have obtained the names of Chinese relatives, friends and frequent associates of American diplomats and other government officials, information that Beijing could use for blackmail or retaliation.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Sidewalk Labs, a Start-Up Created by Google, Has Bold Aims to Improve City Living
articles.snippet: Google’s Sidewalk Labs will pursue technologies to cut pollution, curb energy use, streamline transportation and reduce the cost of city living.
articles.abstract: Google’s Sidewalk Labs will pursue technologies to cut pollution, curb energy use, streamline transportation and reduce the cost of city living.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google’s ambitions and investments have increasingly broadened beyond its digital origins in Internet search and online advertising into the arena of physical objects: self-driving cars, Internet-connected eyeglasses, smart thermostats and a biotech venture to develop life-extending treatments.

articles.headline: Russian Groups Crowdfund the War in Ukraine
articles.snippet: Several groups are running online campaigns to brazenly raise money for rebels in eastern Ukraine, helping succor a conflict that has killed thousands.
articles.abstract: Several groups are running online campaigns to brazenly raise money for rebels in eastern Ukraine, helping succor a conflict that has killed thousands.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Novorossiya Humanitarian Battalion boasts on its website that it provided funds to buy a pair of binoculars used by rebels in eastern Ukraine to spot and destroy an armored vehicle. Another group, Save the Donbass, solicits donations using a photograph of a mortar shell inscribed with its web address and the names of donors. Yet another, Veche, states that its mission is to “create modern, combat-ready” military units fighting Ukraine’s central government.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Amazon’s E-Books Business Investigated by European Antitrust Regulators
articles.snippet: The investigation is the latest hurdle for Amazon and other American tech giants as European policy makers pursue antitrust, tax and other inquiries.
articles.abstract: The investigation is the latest hurdle for Amazon and other American tech giants as European policy makers pursue antitrust, tax and other inquiries.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the digital world, things change in an instant. One minute you are the people’s champion. In the next, perhaps a villain.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Mark Scott

articles.headline: Obama Looks at Adding Bases and Troops in Iraq, to Fight ISIS
articles.snippet: The move would require at least hundreds more American military trainers to help Iraqi forces retake cities lost to the Sunni militants.
articles.abstract: The move would require at least hundreds more American military trainers to help Iraqi forces retake cities lost to the Sunni militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is open to expanding the American military footprint in Iraq with a network of bases and possibly hundreds of additional troops to support Iraqi security forces in their fight against the Islamic State, White House officials said on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Helene Cooper and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Rupert Murdoch to Put Media Empire in Sons’ Hands
articles.snippet: Mr. Murdoch put the succession plan in place in March 2014 when he named his sons James and Lachlan to senior positions in his companies.
articles.abstract: Mr. Murdoch put the succession plan in place in March 2014 when he named his sons James and Lachlan to senior positions in his companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch’s long-held plan to hand over his media empire to his sons is now being realized.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: I.M.F. Recalls Negotiators as Deadline Looms for Greek Deal
articles.snippet: “Major differences” with the government of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras were reported as creditors and Athens pursue a deal.
articles.abstract: “Major differences” with the government of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras were reported as creditors and Athens pursue a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The plotline is familiar by now in Greece’s long-running debt crisis, as bailout talks once again hit a major snag. But at this stage just weeks before the bailout expires, the latest twist could have more serious repercussions.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Landon Thomas Jr
